author: Gramzon Dragon

text:
Konami should remake this game for 3DS and PSvita, fixing all the flaws it has:

*Play the full game on easy mode instead of just playing a half of it.

*Remove the nitro and mandragora part or making it less frustrating

*More items to use in the inventory

*More comfortable saving points.

*Better camera angles.

*More bosses and levels.

*More comfortable whip controls (maybe locking the enemy by pressing L or R like Legend of Zelda).

*Replace the motorcycles by zombie horses and the chainsaw by an axe (is the mid XIX century).

If that happens, surely this game would end up becoming a masterpiece.

author: PeromyscusLeucopus

text: I actually really enjoyed playing through this game and also Legacy of Darkness despite the aggravating camera angles and control issues. The music was fantastic and the adventure was fun!
author: PeromyscusLeucopus

text:
@PeromyscusLeucopus I disagree. Rondo of Blood is too manga to bear the name of Castlevania. Castlevania is a series that should retain its gothic spirit and that's why I withdrew of the serie after the release of Circle of the moon until Lord of shadow, because when I saw it was going in a manga style / metroid / final fantasy, I told myself that it was not a good idea, so I stopped.

But my favorite castlevania is: Super Castlevania 4
author: MauriceTimeofWar

text: @killer7sam If you disregard the anime style intros and just look at the gameplay itself, you will see that the game incorporates everything from all the previous Castlevania games in a perfect manner. It has all the monsters, the main musical themes, the special weapons with added powerups plus adds a new one, but most importantly it keeps the feel of a classic Castlevania action game with the whip wielding gameplay. I'd say the only thing it is lacking is a secret option to play as Simon Belmont. ;-)
author: PeromyscusLeucopus

text: @PeromyscusLeucopus you're right, if rondo of blood had been the only one to be in this style I would have forgiven. But unfortunately (for me) they continued with this style with SOTN. I speak only of the graphic style and not the game itself because SOTN is an excellent game and ROB is a good game, too. But I would have preferred a style closer to SC IV.
author: MauriceTimeofWar

text:
Castlevania 64 is by any stretch of the imagination a very fun game. It's got some excellent music and some cool levels, but it is an inherently flawed game. Definitely underrated, and definitely better than what most people say about it, but I still wouldn't say it's anywhere near as good as SotN. And Symphony isn't even in my top five favorite Castlevania games. 

So while yes, I agree that Castlevania 64 is a very fun game, and not enough people give it credit for being a fun game, I simply can't agree that it's as good as SotN. It has too many little problems bogging it down.

But I'm glad you enjoy the game! I actually find it really cool to know I'm not the only one who liked it, and that there are people who hold it in such high regard.


Oh, and this is one of my favorite Castlevania songs, too.
author: SynthWaveFox0

text:
@SynthWaveFox0  Not as flawed as SOTN though, its a wonder that game didn't kill the series outright. Not that it would have mattered as Konami ended up doing so anyway, just as they did with Contra, Metal Gear and Silent Hill.

R.I.P. Castlevania 1986-2015

text: @Reluctant Warrior I also love the lords of shadow reboot especially the first one that respects at 100% of what must be Castlevania.
author: MauriceTimeofWar

text:
@Reluctant Warrior
I still think that 64 is way more flawed than SOTN. SOTN is very nearly flawless. It had a few issues, as basically any game would. I do think Super Castlevania IV has potential to be one of, if not the best in the series. I do typically prefer the IGA style games. Circle Of The Moon, Aria Of Sorrow, Dawn Of Sorrow, and all the rest are beyond excellent entries. But Castlevania IV is the only one I can say I'm still playing today, over and over again.
author: SynthWaveFox0

text:
@SynthWaveFox0
¬†Just as how Super Mario 64 is more flawed than Super Mario World and Zelda: Ocarina of Time is more flawed than A Link To The Past. The devs had to adapt to making 3D games, its not an easy task. But considering other attempts, Castlevania 64 was fairly successful at entering the third dimension.

I do think SOTN is the weakest of the non-linear Castlevanias. Not a bad game by any means, but compared to the ones that came after(and even Simon's Quest for that matter) it just doesn't compare and is quite tedious(to the point of actually giving Simon's Quest a run for its money).

Personally my personal favorite of the non-linear games would be a tie between Harmony Of Dissonance and Lords Of Shadow 2. But that's just my opinion.

author: Pierre

text:
@Name Holder all right, let me compare castlevania 64 with the others castlevania 3D (lament of innocence and curse of darkness). Boring? For sure traverse some LONG empty corridors with no enemies is better? The atmosphere of castlevania 64 is the darkest and the most unique and it will always be better than making multiple copy and paste to the atmosphere of SOTN.

Shit puzzles? In the game there must be I think 2 or 3 puzzles, and I'm trying to remember but there is absolutely ZERO puzzle in lament of innocence and curse of darkness. In addition, the puzzles of CV64 are very well thought out.

The level design of Castlevania 64 is just great and is 1000 times better than your empty corridors.



the controls are not bad at all, you must get used to and then you can really have fun and it's like that with ANY game on the planet. It is sure that when you're used to always play the same metroidvania with controls unchanged, necessarily IGAfanboy don't like it.

Awful framerate? The game only slows when there is a lot of enemies on the screen (but this happens only in the first level) or when there is a lot of flames on screen. I agree the frame rate is not perfect but the game is perfectly playable.

Looks ugly? the game is just beautiful and the art direction is a lot better than LOI and COD. And unlike the other castlevania you really feel to explore a HUGE castle. So to say such a thing you should probably hate the N64 or if not all the games from the N64 are ugly.


Here, so before saying stupid things inform you a minimum and try to give him a second chance without your prejudices. You will be surprised that this game is really AWESOME and he's really underrated :).
author: MauriceTimeofWar

text:
@killer7sam Those are some perfectly legitimate reasons not to like the game. Personally, I never had those issues. I'm a big fan of the art style used in that game and I think it's a very well made game in general.

You do make a good point about the selection of items. It had a pretty terrible selection.
I can see why you might not have enjoyed it as much as the other games.

I'm curious to know, by the way, did you enjoy Lords of Shadow? It was a pretty big departure from the IGA style of games. I actually thought Lords of Shadow reminded me a lot of Castlevania 64, so I'm curious to know whether or not you liked it.
author: SynthWaveFox0

text:
@SynthWaveFox0
¬†I think its because Lords Of Shadow felt like a combination of Super Castlevania IV and Castlevania 64, which is probably why it was such a solid game.
author: Reluctant Warrior ‚ìã

text:
+killer7sam I don't think SotN is overrated, but I do think C64 was an awesome game. Its too bad it wasn't as popular. I remember most people complained about the controls and the character's mobility, they seemed fine to me, and I remember enjoyed this game too much. Oh well.

Ironically, this is the only 3D castlevania that I've ever liked. CastleGodOfWar for 360/PS3 might have been fun for some, but not for me.

author: faeriecrypt

text: Awesome :), you should try the others this series is excellent.
author: MauriceTimeofWar

text:
+MauriceTimeofWar It's not as good as Belmont's Revenge, but certainly better than The Adventure (which is not hard, since CVA is a horrible mess). Overall, it's an average game, not exceptionally good, nor exceptionally bad, IMO.


I don't have issues with it being removed from the timeline. It was a mediocre story, which was quite weak for a start of legendary feud between Dracula and Belmont clan. Dracula was never given proper introduction in it, he is just already there and that's it. 


On other hand, story of Lament of Innocence is a full scale dramatic nonsense. It has its good moments and I liked voice acting, but generally it's just typical IGA's run-of-the-mill story (one friend betrays another, an idea, which is present almost in all his games, though arguably the first game, which utilized this plot was KCEK's Legacy of Darkness).


So, both origins are quite bad, for their own reasons. Legends is too low-key and LOI feels boring.
author: ShadowSumac

text: +ShadowSumac I am partially agree, of course Legends can not be enough in itself to tell the origins of the series. But this is not a sufficient reason to remove it, Igarashi could have very well make his Lament of innocence without removing Legends from the timeline. Besides, Lament of Innocence was a huge disappointment for me. I'm not satisfied with the answers provided to the questions that I asked myself. I prefer the origins told in Lords of Shadow rather than Lament of Innocence.
author: MauriceTimeofWar

text:
1000% Agreed. This is the first 3D Castlevania and the sountrack, mechanics, atmosphere and every sound FX are so marvellous... with a masterful main menu and the first impression with that giant skeleton boss is so great!

IDK... but the little details of this game make it the best 3D Castlevania and one game who every gamer must play.

On the topic of the classic Castlevania - Castlevania IV and X are the best in that order-

The metroidvania i appreciate on the other ways. Also great games but are another cathegory.

author: Otaku Lord8

text: As much as the N64 Castlevanias are flawed and hated, I had a LOT of fun with them and I find them to be the most atmospheric 3D entries in the series to date. I really felt the kind of oppressive and desolate feeling I wanted to get from the games. They remind me of Super Castlevania 4 in the way the setting and ambiance immerses you. Lament of Innocence was such a boring, formulaic and joyless game I can barely believe I brought myself to finish it.

author: Cardboard Box

text: It would've been perfect if the lock-feature made you strafe like in the 64 zelda games. That's the one thing I wouldn't have minded them ripping off shamelessly. As it is whenever you want to dodge you have to come to a complete stop first and then press the analog stick in time with the jump button, which is plain unreliable. It also doesn't help that you can only lock-on in battle mode, and sometimes the game will automatically switch to action mode instead. I wouldn't be surprised if many people didn't even know there as a lock-on system at all.

author: Griseus Lupus

text: It's a fucking great game, but Legacy of Darkness (basically an updated version) is an absolute masterpiece, one of the best games ever made. I have a theory as to why it has so many haters: It's the same as Nickelback, most people hate on it because everybody else does, when in reality they never even played it. As for the game itself, it may be different from its predecessors, but that does not mean it's bad. The atmosphere is incredible, the gameplay is solid (I never understood why people complain about the controls/camera, I didn't have any trouble with them even when I first played the game) the soundtrack is a masterpiece, the sound design is probably the best on the N64, the scenery/levels are very well designed and feel massive, the graphics are quite good for N64 and the story isn't anything special, but it's there, and has more depth to it and its characters than in most other Castlevania games. That said, there are some flaws. The one that bothers me is that the levels are laid out like an open/semi-open world game (how you can backtrack and all that) but the game is completely linear. If it was at least semi-linear, it probably would've been pretty interesting. Also, I find it a very easy game, even on the Hard difficulty, but that's probably because I beat it about 3 million times.
author: GSV
